 Actually, a good question that I am sure many people have, but were unable to state so clearly. 
 
 First and foremost, Terri did not have a heart attack at age 26. A heart attack (myocardial infarction, literally meaning death of heart muscle) is brought about by a blockage of blood flow to a coronary artery whether by build up of plaque, a clot, or spasm of the artery. A true "heart attack" results in damage to the heart muscle, due to the lack of blood flow and subsequent lack of oxygen. This is much like what happened to Terri's brain when she collapsed so many years ago. 
 
 Terri suffered a cardiac arrest. A cardiac arrest is when the heart stops beating, and can be brought about by a variety of causes. Chemical imbalance (such as sodium, calcium, or potassium), electrical disturbance, heart attacks, or even trauma can all cause cardiac arrest. In Terri's case, it is believed that she had a dangerously low potassium, as you pointed out. 
 
 You hit on a good point too, that it is unknown how fast Terri lost her weight, or what her dietary habits (including purging by vomiting, laxatives, or excessive hydration) really were. Just because Terri was 26 and weight appropriate does not indicate that she was healthy. Bulemia is a dangerous and potentially deadly disease, and if Terri truely was bulemic, it is highly likely that this led to her cardiac arrest.
 
 As you may or may not know, the heart relies upon sodium, potassium, calcium, and several other elements to function. Potassium in the heart is vital to the operation of the sodium-potassium pump, which provides for electrical depolarization and repolarization of the heart. This is what is responsible for the electrical signals that stimulate the contraction and relaxation of the cardiac muscle. ANY disturbance in the balance of these elements (either too little or too much) can cause an electrical malfunction, and potentiate a lethal dysrhythmia (unorganized or abnormal heart rhythm). It is actually an overdose of potassium that is used to stop the heart in lethal injection cases.
 
 It is likely that as Terri died in the hospice a few days ago, that she died due to a chemical imbalance, which ultimately stopped her heart. (I know you said you did not want to hear someone say that her heart stopping killed her, but I must in all honesty say: It was her heart stopping that killed her). Terri was maintained by the feeding tube, which provided adequate nutrition to keep her alive. This type of nutrition is balanced to provide the right amount of elements and nutrients to maintain normal body chemistry. Once the feeding tube was removed from Terri, she began to become chemically imbalanced due to the lack of nutrition. The lack of water caused her kidneys to shut down, which in turn led to a change in the chemical balance in Terri's body. Ultimately, this chemical imbalance would lead to a dsyrhythmia that would stop her heart. 
 
 You said about her level of potassium "plummeting" without food and water. Actually, levels would change slowly, keep in mind that her electrolytes were probably in balance prior to removal of the feeding tube. The levels would change more rapidly after her kidneys failed, but this still takes somewhere from 7-10 days on average to occur. And also, keep in mind that Terri was inactive, which would allow her to sustain her electrolyte levels easier than you or I. 
 
 You also mention anorexic people. First, Terri was thought to be bulemic, which is a different disorder. Second, it is very possible for the human body to create a tolerance of an electrolyte imbalance over an extended period of time. Alcoholics are a good example of this. Although not healthy, many people can survive with significant electrolyte imbalances. 
 
 So basically, Terri died of a cardiac arrest which was caused by an electrolyte imbalance. Yes, you can say that Terri dehydrated to death, but it is the electrolyte imbalance caused by the dehyfration that actually stopped Terri's heart.
